fields.headline: Eating into pensions
fields.bodyText: Given mounting obesity among adolescents, your front page on April 22 quoted an expert saying that today's youths may die earlier than their parents. This possibility is stated every so often, but I have never seen it mentioned in the context of the debate over pensions, where it is assumed that life expectancy will continue rising. And so, it is suggested, must the retirement age. Adolescence has always been a confusing time, but now youngsters have to anticipate both dying earlier and having to work longer to provide for a much extended old age. Phillip Hall London Stephen Wood's suggestion (Letters, April 24) that female runners being paced by men is an American invention is incorrect and unfair to Deena Kastor. Women of many nationalities have used male pacemakers - such as Paula Radclffe when she won the London Marathon in a world record time in 2003. Mark Redhead London Which republican mole scheduled BBC1's programmes on Sunday on BBC1? The Queen at 80: A Family Service from Windsor Castle was followed by As Time Goes By, Last of the Summer Wine and The Antiques Roadshow. Later a double dose of Waking the Dead rounded off the main evening programmes. David Bush Cambridge Mods used to hang rabbits' tails from their aerials (Sixty Stylish Years of the Vespa, April 24)? They wouldn't have flapped about much, would they? More likely to have been a fox tail or similar. Ralph Jones Rochester, Kent Your report (Crowds force closure of theme park, April 17) tells us the drop in the new Thorpe Park rollercoaster is (a) vertical and (b) the fourth steepest in the world. Clearly the other three rides must penetrate into the fifth dimension. Dr Fergus Lalor Cork, Ireland "By 2002," writes Eric Schlosser (Stuff the kids, G2, April 24), "the top five food advertisers in the UK were McDonald's, Coca-Cola, KFC and Pizza Hut." Eric's been eating too many burgers. John Whiting London
